name: theory_of_mind
description: short story presented with a question at the end, participants must answer the question.
reference: Saxe, R. and Kanwisher, N. (2003) ‘People thinking about thinking people: The role of the temporo-parietal junction in “theory of mind”’, NeuroImage, 19(4), pp. 1835–1842. Available at: https://doi.org/10.1016/S1053-8119(03)00230-1.

name: verb_generation
description: Words presented, participants read the words. At halfpoint, "GENERATE" is shown, participants need to covertly generate verbs associated with words

name: rest
description: lie in scanner with a fixation cross

name: tongue_movement
description: move tongue from right to left, touching upper premolar teeth guided by a flashing black circle around a fixation crosshair, black circle means right no cirlce means left, 1s periods
reference: A Third Somatomotor Representation in the Human Cerebellum (Bucknet et al., 2022)

name: auditory_narrative
description: 30 second snippets of a moth radiohour story (wheretheressmoke)

name: semantic_prediction
description: sentence presented, participants decide if last word makes sense.

name: visual_search
description: geometric shapes presented on screen, participants must identify if 'L' is present.

name: rmet
description: pictures of faces with different emotions presented (eyes only) along with four attribute words, participants must identify which attribute describes person best.
reference: Kim, H.A. et al. (2024) ‘Multiracial Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test (MRMET): An inclusive version of an influential measure’, Behavior Research Methods. Revised from Baron-Cohen, Wheelwright, Hill, Raste, & Plumb, 2001

name: picture_sequence
description: 4 cartoon pictures are presented, participants must order them chronologically.
reference: Heleven, E., van Dun, K. and Van Overwalle, F. (2019) ‘The posterior Cerebellum is involved in constructing Social Action Sequences: An fMRI Study’, Scientific Reports, 9(1), pp. 1–11. Available at: https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-019-46962-7.

name: story_sequence
description: 4 sentences are presented, participants must order them chronologically.
reference: Heleven, E., van Dun, K. and Van Overwalle, F. (2019) ‘The posterior Cerebellum is involved in constructing Social Action Sequences: An fMRI Study’, Scientific Reports, 9(1), pp. 1–11. Available at: https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-019-46962-7.

name: action_prediction
description: An action video is shown where an actor is either taking a penalty shot or greeting a person, participants must predict if the ball lands left or right or if the person greets with a handshake or hug.
reference: King, M. (2022). Investigating cortico-cerebellar contributions to cognition. UC Berkeley. ProQuest ID: King_berkeley_0028E_21350. Merritt ID: ark:/13030/m5wb6kvd. Retrieved from https://escholarship.org/uc/item/61w6t6sk

name: movie
description: 30s clips of planet earth documentary or of a pixar movie, no audio no subtitles
reference: Planet Earth and Pixar UP" movie as used in King, M. et al. (2019) ‘Functional boundaries in the human cerebellum revealed by a multi-domain task battery’, Nature Neuroscience, 22(8), pp. 1371–1378. Available at: https://doi.org/10.1038/s41593-019-0436-x."

name: strange_stories
description: clips of relationship stories, participants are asked to answer questions about the interaction
reference: Murray, K. et al. (2017) ‘A new test of advanced theory of mind: The “Strange Stories Film Task” captures social processing differences in adults with autism spectrum disorders’, Autism Research, 10(6), pp. 1120–1132. Available at: https://doi.org/10.1002/aur.1744.

name: faux_pas
description: stories of (potential) faux pas situations, participants must answer questions about the interaction
reference: Stone, V.E., Baron-Cohen, S. & Knight, R.T. (1998). Frontal lobe contributions to theory of mind. Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience, 10, 640-656. Gregory, C. , Lough, S., Stone, V.E., Erzinclioglu, S., Martin, L., Baron-Cohen, S. & Hodges, J. (2002). Theory of mind in frontotemporal dementia and Alzheimer's disease: Theoretical and practical implications. Brain, 125, 752-64.

name: frith_happe
description: video clips of triangle animations, participants must determine whether interaction was random, goal-directed or a mentalizing interaction
reference: Livingston, L.A. et al. (2021) ‘Further developing the Frith–Happé animations: A quicker, more objective, and web-based test of theory of mind for autistic and neurotypical adults’, Autism Research, 14(9), pp. 1905–1912. Available at: https://doi.org/10.1002/aur.2575..

name: liking
description: video clips of people interacting, participants must determine if the interaction was positive or negative
reference: Heerey, E.A. and Gilder, T.S.E. (2019) ‘The subjective value of a smile alters social behaviour’, PLoS ONE, 14(12), pp. 1–19. Available at: https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0225284.
